articles.headline: Immigration Overhaul Wins Panel’s Backing in the Senate
articles.snippet: The Senate Judiciary Committee, voting 13 to 5 to approve a bill drafted by a bipartisan group of eight senators, agreed to hold off on an amendment that would have added protections for gay couples.
articles.abstract: The Senate Judiciary Committee, voting 13 to 5 to approve a bill drafted by a bipartisan group of eight senators, agreed to hold off on an amendment that would have added protections for gay couples.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday approved a broad overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws on a bipartisan vote, sending the most significant immigration policy changes in decades to the full Senate, where the debate is expected to begin next month.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Julia Preston

articles.headline: Disarming Senators, Apple Chief Eases Tax Tensions
articles.snippet: Tim Cook came to Capitol Hill prepared to face down senators furious over evidence that Apple had avoided paying billions in taxes, but he left having won many of them over.
articles.abstract: Tim Cook came to Capitol Hill prepared to face down senators furious over evidence that Apple had avoided paying billions in taxes, but he left having won many of them over.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Timothy Cook came to the lion’s den on Capitol Hill on Tuesday, prepared to face down lawmakers furious over evidence that Apple, the famous company he runs, had avoided paying billions in taxes. By the time Mr. Cook walked out, the big cats on a Senate committee were practically eating out of his hand.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Next Xbox Will Face New Array of Rivals
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s new game console also serves as a home entertainment hub, a response to the rising popularity of mobile devices for playing games.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s new game console also serves as a home entertainment hub, a response to the rising popularity of mobile devices for playing games.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — Microsoft is betting it has a new way to win the wallets of consumers.

articles.headline: A Pearl Buck Novel, New After 4 Decades
articles.snippet: “The Eternal Wonder,” an unpublished novel by Pearl S. Buck that surfaced last year in a storage unit, is to be released this fall by Open Road Integrated Media.
articles.abstract: “The Eternal Wonder,” an unpublished novel by Pearl S. Buck that surfaced last year in a storage unit, is to be released this fall by Open Road Integrated Media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forty years after being written, an unpublished novel by Pearl S. Buck, the Nobel laureate and Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist, will be released this fall, her publisher said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: A Keynesian Victory, but Austerity Stands Firm
articles.snippet: Fiscal stimulus appears to have won the intellectual argument among economists, but governments and voters still favor austerity.
articles.abstract: Fiscal stimulus appears to have won the intellectual argument among economists, but governments and voters still favor austerity.
articles.lead_paragraph: To go by the statements of most mainstream economists, one would be forgiven for believing this is the best of times for Keynesian economics.

articles.headline: A Magnet for Shoppers Is Getting a Makeover
articles.snippet: Woodbury Common, a labyrinthine outlet complex north of New York City that draws shoppers from all over the world, is preparing for an expansion and an extensive overhaul.
articles.abstract: Woodbury Common, a labyrinthine outlet complex north of New York City that draws shoppers from all over the world, is preparing for an expansion and an extensive overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitra Suleiman drives seven hours to Central Valley, N.Y., from her home in Ottawa, Canada, every year in search of a bargain.

articles.headline: For U.S. Companies, Money ‘Offshore’ Means Manhattan
articles.snippet: In the convoluted world of corporate tax accounting, corporate money that is technically overseas is often held in American banks.
articles.abstract: In the convoluted world of corporate tax accounting, corporate money that is technically overseas is often held in American banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like some of the nation’s prominent chief executives, Apple’s Timothy D. Cook has a simple proposal to help spur the economy and encourage corporate tax compliance: give American companies a tax break to bring to the United States untaxed profits parked overseas.

articles.headline: Debate Aside, Number of Drone Strikes Drops Sharply
articles.snippet: In an address on Thursday, President Obama will attempt to lay out his justification for drone strikes, which have been in decline since 2010, and what they have achieved.
articles.abstract: In an address on Thursday, President Obama will attempt to lay out his justification for drone strikes, which have been in decline since 2010, and what they have achieved.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama embraced drone strikes in his first term, and the targeted killing of suspected terrorists has come to define his presidency.

articles.headline: Why No Safe Room to Run To? Cost and Plains Culture
articles.snippet: In states like Oklahoma and Missouri, tornadoes are a seasonal threat, but government regulation and the expense of shelters rankle.
articles.abstract: In states like Oklahoma and Missouri, tornadoes are a seasonal threat, but government regulation and the expense of shelters rankle.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Web site for the City of Moore, Okla., recommends “that every residence have a storm safe room or an underground cellar.” It says below-ground shelters are the best protection against tornadoes.

articles.headline: Fed Endorses Stimulus, but the Message Is Garbled
articles.snippet: The Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, supported the central bank’s bond-buying effort, but some officials were already thinking about scaling it back.
articles.abstract: The Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, supported the central bank’s bond-buying effort, but some officials were already thinking about scaling it back.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite signs of improvement in the job market, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, and most other Fed officials signaled Wednesday that they remained cautious about easing back too quickly on their efforts to stimulate the economy.
